Expectation1: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation1: A procedural hearing on a minor matter can easily be postponed if necessary.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I checked my watch for the third time, feeling the weight of my briefcase in one hand and my voter registration card in the other. As a lawyer, I knew the court hearing scheduled for later was minor—just a procedural matter that could be postponed if I absolutely had to. Still, I prided myself on being reliable for my clients, always showing up, always prepared. But today, I was also a voter, determined to fulfill my civic duty.

The line at the polling station snaked around the block, but it was moving steadily. Suddenly, an official called out, “Voters with last names A–M, please move to the new line!” My last name started with B. The new line looked longer and slower, but the instructions were clear. As a lawyer, I was trained to follow rules and respect authority, but as a voter pressed for time, I wanted to stay put and get through quickly.

My heart pounded as I hesitated, torn between the urge to follow the official’s directions and the need to get to court on time. The expectations of both roles pressed in on me, and I stood frozen, caught between duty and practicality.
